pullRequest.body:
Using a `@[csimp]` attribute we can replace `npowRec` at runtime with an algorithm that uses repeated squaring,
without affecting the definitional properties of `npowRec`.

The prototypical application is that
```
#eval (3 : ZMod 49999)^49998
```
used to stack overflow, but now runs fine.

(This is an output of the "Formalization and Computer Algebra Systems" group at https://aimath.org/workshops/upcoming/cyberinfrastructure/.)

---

- [x] depends on: #8884

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

I believe everyone's concerns have been addressed. There other PR (https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9154) is a few dependent PRs deep. I don't think it makes sense to wait. 

Please address the merge conflicts created by #6262 removing the default values for `npow` and `zpow` and then send it off.

Thanks. I think this is really great for connections to computation. 

bors delegate+

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562609)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562939)
Looks good to me
Looks good to me

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (_add_zero : âˆ€ m : M, m + 0 = m) (_zero_add : âˆ€ m : M, 0 + m = m) (k : â„•) (m : M) : M := ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (_mul_one : âˆ€ m : M, m * 1 = m) (_one_mul : âˆ€ m : M, 1 * m = m) (k : â„•) (m : M) : M := ```
Golfing welcome ...!

Using my definition above, I get
```lean
lemma npowBinRec_eq_npowRec {M : Type*} [Semigroup M] [One M]
    (_mul_one : âˆ€ m : M, m * 1 = m) (_one_mul : âˆ€ m : M, 1 * m = m) (k : â„•) (m : M)  :
    npowBinRec _mul_one _one_mul k m = npowRec k m := by
  have : âˆ€ n, npowRec (n + n) m = npowRec n m * npowRec n m := sorry
  dsimp [npowBinRec]
  induction k using Nat.binaryRec' with
  | z => simp [npowRec]
  | f b n hb ih =>
    rw [Nat.binaryRec_of_ne_zero]
    simp [Nat.bodd_bit, ih, Nat.div2_bit]
    cases b <;> simp [bit0, bit1, this, npowRec, mul_assoc]
```
I'll resolve this suggestion, as that alternative definition isn't useful here.

What do you think of:
```suggestion
def npowBinRec {M : Type*} [Semigroup M] [One M]
    (_mul_one : âˆ€ m : M, m * 1 = m) (_one_mul : âˆ€ m : M, 1 * m = m) (k : â„•) (m : M) : M :=
  Nat.binaryRec (C := fun _ => M) 1 (fun b n mn => bif b then m * mn * mn else mn * mn) k
```

This stack overflows at

```
import Mathlib.Data.ZMod.Defs

def k := 17
def p := 2^k - 1
#eval (37 : ZMod p)^(p-1)
```

while the current implementation is happily running at `k := 23209` (and presumably goes further if you are patient).
If you could work out how to make `Nat.binaryRec` produce tail-recursive code, that would be lovely, but maybe out of scope here.

This will conflict with #6262, and probably also with the proposal on Zulip to weaken `npowRec` to power-associativity.

Perhaps the compromise here is to only use this optimized recursive version for `ZMod`/`Nat`/`Int`/`Rat`?

It doesn't seem like there is much conflict? If you want to remove the default, just advise users to use this new default instead.

(We could provide another wrapper around `npowRec'` that has `Semigroup` / `MulOneClass` hypotheses rather than the unpacked `mul_one` and `one_mul` fields. This can't be used in the default value for `Monoid` itself, but if it is provided downstream that isn't a problem.)

Similarly, the new `npowBinRec` and associated proofs could be trivially refactored to only use power associativity rather than associativity.

The problem is that you can't supply the `add_zero` and `zero_add` arguments if the user fills the field explicitly; self-references are only allowed in default values.



> (We could provide another wrapper around `npowRec'` that has `Semigroup` / `MulOneClass` hypotheses)

This unfortunately doesn't work, as then we get `Mul` twice. We could have a `Monoid.WithoutPowYet` typeclass that extends both, but that's obviously pretty ugly...

I'm confused by what the objection is here, to be honest. #6262 proposes removing default values, and instead writing them in concrete instances; can't it do that equally well before or after this PR?
@eric-wieser, I agree with Scott. I don't see what the problem is. Can you be more explicit?

(I'd really like to be able to proceed with this change, as it enables the demo that @robertylewis and I were working on with some CAS developers at a recent workshop. Shipping the demo is a chance to advertise Lean's capabilities to the CAS world.)

Sorry, let me be more explicit:

On master, we can write
```lean
instance : Monoid Foo where
  one := sorry
  mul := sorry
  one_mul := sorry
  mul_one := sorry
  mul_assoc := sorry
```
With #6262 (or at least, the `pow` version of it), we can no longer write that, because if we add `npow := npowRec` then Lean can't find the `1` or `*` in time. So we have to write
```lean
instance : Mul Foo where
  mul := sorry

instance : One Foo where
  one := sorry

instance : Monoid Foo where
  one_mul := sorry
  mul_one := sorry
  mul_assoc := sorry
  npow := npowRec
```
with #6262 + this change, things get even worse, because we need to set up all the previous smaller structures before we can call `npowRec'`
```lean
instance : Mul Foo where
  mul := sorry

instance : One Foo where
  one := sorry

instance : MulOneClass Foo where
  one_mul := sorry
  mul_one := sorry

instance : Semigroup Foo where
  mul_assoc := sorry

instance : Monoid Foo where
  npow := npowRec mul_one one_mul -- slightly more annoying
```

Essentially the problem is that default arguments have magic powers that regular arguments cannot attain, and your proposal uses more of those magical powers.

Note that my objection is only to setting the default power operation; I'm very happy for it to be manually overriden on a handful of types to pique the interest of the CAS people.
Okay. My preference is still to proceed with this PR. If the decision is not too, I can eventually make this change just on Int/Nat/ZMod/etc, but not for at least a few weeks.
@eric-wieser Could we have this PR and a custom constructor for `Monoid`, and get the best of both worlds that way?
Given #12608, I am resolving this thread. Please let me know if I am mistaken.

Here's a way to eliminate this repetition between the `smul` and `pow` versions:
```lean
/-- Fold `f` across the bits of `n` -/
def foldBits {Ïƒ} (f : Bool â†’ Ïƒ â†’ Ïƒ) (init : Ïƒ) (n : â„•) : Ïƒ :=
  match n, init with
  | 0, s => s
  | (k + 1), s =>
    let k' := (k + 1) >>> 1
    foldBits f (f (k &&& 1 == 1) s) k'
  termination_by foldBits f _ k => k
  -- We use this `decreasing_by` block rather than inline `have` statements to avoid
  -- https://github.com/leanprover/std4/issues/428
  decreasing_by
    simp_wf
    exact Nat.div_lt_self (Nat.zero_lt_succ _) (Nat.lt_succ_self _)

@[to_additive]
def npowBinRec' {M : Type*} [Semigroup M] [One M]
    (_add_zero : âˆ€ m : M, m * 1 = m) (_zero_add : âˆ€ m : M, 1 * m = m) (k : â„•) (m : M) : M :=
  Prod.fst <| foldBits (fun b p => (if b then p.1 else p.1 * p.2, p.2 * p.2)) (1, m) k
```
Does this still produce something tail-recursive?

It must be, right? `foldBits` is the head symbol of the recursion.

(I guess you could inline `k'` if the `let` concerns you, that's vestigial from an earlier attempt anyway)
I don't think I've ever written a tail recursive function via well founded recursion, and am not certain it actually works!

@semorrison, I have no idea what you're talking about. The original lines that I am suggesting a replacement for are themselves a tail recursive function via well founded recursion, that I assume was written by you! All I've done is factor out the common piece.

Eric's `foldBits` suggestion seems like it would generate fine code, so long as it's marked `@[inline]`. If you go with it, be sure to specify what "fold over the bits" means. Presumably from least- to most- significant bits? It seems to go until the zero bit right above the the most-significant set bit?

I'm not sure whether the compiler will split the product type into separate arguments, so it might actually produce slightly worse code. I don't think the code duplication here is that bad, and maybe if you're interested in an API for folding over bits @eric-wieser you can pursue this after this PR is merged?
I think it's also worth considering (or ruling out) the approach in #9154 here, which claims that `binaryRec` works fine after all.

> @semorrison, I have no idea what you're talking about. The original lines that I am suggesting a replacement for are themselves a tail recursive function via well founded recursion, that I assume was written by you! All I've done is factor out the common piece.

Sorry, yes, I was confused.
I've asked @negiizhao if they can update #9154; hopefully that will work out.

Nit: you could instead use
```suggestion
abbrev npowRec' {M : Type*} [MulOneClass M]
    (_mul_assoc : sorry) (k : â„•) (m : M) : M :=
```
to reduce the number of arguments here (and for the others too)
This no longer seems relevant so I am resolving. Please let me know if I am wrong.
To avoid `Group/Defs` growing with things that aren't really the definition of groups, can we move these (and the `BinRec` functions) to `Algebra/Group/FastPower` or something?

One downside of that is it means you could be using the slow version just because you hadn't imported `Algebra.Group.FastPower` in addition to `Algebra.Group.Defs`. Where do you imagine `Algebra.Group.FastPower` would get imported in mathlib? It doesn't seem like any file would strictly need it, but if it was only transitively included by `import Mathlib` that would be a minimization footgun. In general, it seems to me that it's sketchy for later files to change the behavior of declarations from earlier ones.

Another option would be to mark `npowRec'` as `noncomputable` and add a doc comment saying "Import `Algebra.Group.FastPower` to use `npowRec'` inside computable definitions." I believe adding a `@[csimp]` lemma does make noncomputable declarations computable.
I would prefer this as a follow up if it is desired.

```suggestion
A variant of `npowRec` which is a semigroup homomorphisms from `â„•â‚Š` to `M`.
```

```suggestion
A variant of `nsmulRec` which is a semigroup homomorphisms from `â„•â‚Š` to `M`.
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: use @[csimp] to use exponentiation by repeated squaring at runtime
